title: 107_s1035
content: The "Great Lakes Preservation Act" may be cited as the official title of this legislation. The Act includes findings related to the Great Lakes. Congress finds that the Great Lakes are precious public natural resources crucial to the economies of the Great Lakes States, containing 1/5 of the world's fresh water supply and serving as a vital source of safe drinking water for millions of people. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 is a voluntary international agreement that provides a procedural framework for notice and consultation by the Great Lakes States and Provinces regarding water diversion. Governors and Premiers base decisions on water proposals on conservation and protection efforts. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 outlines procedures for water diversion proposals, emphasizing conservation and protection efforts. Decision-making on Great Lakes water should remain with the Governors of the Great Lakes States. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Administrator" refers to the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. "Bulk fresh water" is fresh water extracted for transportation without further processing. "From the Great Lakes basin" refers to water from specific lakes or interconnecting waterways. The term "Great Lake" refers to Lake Erie, Lake Huron, Lake Michigan, and Lake Ontario. It includes water from interconnecting waterways and tributaries within the watershed that drains into these lakes. The term "Great Lakes Province" refers to Ontario or Quebec, Canada, while "Great Lakes State" includes Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, or Wisconsin. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary. The term "Great Lakes State" includes Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, or Wisconsin. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service. Moratorium on export of bulk fresh water. Moratorium on export of bulk fresh water from the Great Lakes basin within the United States, with a provision for cessation upon approval of a conservation standard by Congress and regional authorities. Sense of Congress is that the US should agree with Canada to uphold the moratorium on exporting water from the Great Lakes until a specified date. SEC. 5. PRESERVATION OF HISTORIC GREAT LAKES LIGHTHOUSES. The Great Lakes have influenced settlement, commerce, and recreation in the region. Lighthouses in the area have aided mariners for decades, many with historical or architectural significance. However, neglect and deterioration threaten the future of these important structures. The future of Great Lakes lighthouses is uncertain due to neglect and deterioration. The Secretary will conduct a study to identify options for preserving these structures within 3 years. The National Park Service will determine how to preserve Great Lakes lighthouses and associated resources. They will consult with State and local historical associations, historic preservation agencies, the Coast Guard Commandant, and other relevant entities. Appropriations are authorized for this purpose.
